description.overview: Engineers are masters of robotics and nanotechnology, capable of deploying and controlling various types of robots for combat, defense, and utility purposes. They also specialize in nanoprogramming for additional support.

system.flashback_trigger: When an earlier invention or repair could be beneficial now.
system.flashback_effect: Roll to reveal you had previously crafted or repaired a device that is pivotal in the current scenario.
system.signature_resource_desc: At the start of an encounter or after being deployed, the android begins in a basic operational state. Its abilities and performance are limited due to the need for synchronization with the Engineer.
system.signature_resource_effect:
Synchronization Phases:

Phase 1 (Initial Rounds): The android operates with reduced effectiveness. It might have slower movement, lower attack power, or limited access to its abilities.
Phase 2 (Mid-Encounter): As the encounter progresses, the android begins to sync more closely with the Engineer. Its capabilities start to improve, unlocking more actions per turn or gaining access to advanced skills.
Phase 3 (Full Synchronization): After several rounds (e.g., after 3-5 rounds), the android reaches full synchronization. It now operates at peak capacity, gaining significant boosts to its abilities, speed, strength, and access to its full range of skills and functions.
Mechanics:

Synchronization Die: Represent the synchronization level with a die (e.g., d6). Start at 1, and at the end of each round, increase the die by 1. Each number represents a phase of synchronization.
Bonuses and Abilities: Each phase confers specific bonuses or abilities to the android. For example, at Phase 3, the android might gain double movement speed or a powerful attack ability. Reset: If the android is deactivated, destroyed, or encounters a significant disruption, synchronization resets, requiring the process to start over.
Commanding the Droid in Combat:
Issue commands for Attack, Defend, or Special Abilities.
Effective within a specific range of the Engineer.
Abilities may have cooldowns.

Neural Synchronization: Engineers require a direct neural link to control their robots. This link allows for precise commands and real-time adjustments, but due to its complexity, an Engineer can maintain synchronization with only one robot at a time.

advancements.effect: +1 ER when targeted by Ranged Attacks

advancements.effect: +1 ER when targeted by an area of effect attack or explosion

skill_list.name: Gadgeteer
skill_list.description:
• Designing, modifying, and using a diverse range of gadgets.
  • Inventing custom gadgets for surveillance, espionage, or utility.
  • Enhancing or repurposing existing devices for specific tasks.
  • Rapid on-field gadget improvisation and adaptation.

skill_list.name: Tradeskiller
skill_list.description:
• Expertise in a variety of trade skills, including crafting, repair, and construction.
  • Crafting and repairing a wide range of items, from simple tools to complex machinery.
  • Utilizing trade skills for practical solutions in diverse situations.
  • Repairing and upgrading vehicles or mechanical equipment.

skill_list.name: Rigger
skill_list.description:
• Remotely operating and controlling machinery or drones through mental commands.
  • Piloting drones or vehicles for reconnaissance, combat, or exploration.
  • Utilizing remote machinery for tasks in hazardous or inaccessible areas.
  • Coordinating multiple machines or automated systems simultaneously.

skill_list.name: Creator
skill_list.description:
• Innovative invention and groundbreaking technological development.
  • Developing new technologies or prototypes.
  • Experimenting with advanced materials or energy sources.
  • Leading technological projects that push the boundaries of science.

skill_list.name: Nobel Prize
skill_list.description:
• Achieving recognition for significant contributions to engineering and technology.
  • Using facts and logic to convince others.
  • Collaborating with elite scientists and tech experts.
  • Influencing major technological trends and advancements.

nanoprograms.name: Plasma Shield
nanoprograms.effect: Target+Hits gain a shield and are resistant to Energy damage and gains 5+ Hits RES

nanoprograms.name: Aegis Barrier
nanoprograms.effect: Improves Target + Hits armor by 1 tier.

nanoprograms.name: A Maker’s Touch
nanoprograms.effect: Target machine is  repaired and heals physically damaged technology. The healing is NR x Hits

nanoprograms.name: Intrusive Aura of the Humble Servant
nanoprograms.effect: Targets Engaged with an allied Machine lose 1+Hits Initiative

nanoprograms.name: Extreme Prejudice
nanoprograms.effect: Overloads a piece of technology rigged to explode dealing NR x Hits damage upon triggering.

nanoprograms.name: Philosopher’s Stone
nanoprograms.effect: Upgrades a target’s Tradeskill Tests by 1+Hits and increases their Supply Point maximum by 2

nanoprograms.name: Miniaturization
nanoprograms.effect: Reduce the size of machine target + Hits by 1 step.

nanoprograms.name: Formula 22
nanoprograms.effect: Target+ machine gain 2 Agility and can perform 1 minor action

nanoprograms.name: Geo-Resonance Field
nanoprograms.effect: Deploys a terrain-altering energy field that creates a barrier that provides cover and hinders movement.

nanoprograms.name: Reactive Harmonic Cocoon
nanoprograms.effect: Creates a cocoon around you that reflects damage back at the attacker. The attacker receives half the damage they deal back at them.

signature_traits.name: Rigging
signature_traits.description:
Rigging is an advanced form of technological control that Engineers use to connect their consciousness directly with their mechanical creations. Through their specialized NCU, Engineers can 'jump in' to their drones or robots, experiencing the world through their sensors and exerting precise control over their actions. This direct link allows for intricate maneuvers and strategic deployment in various scenarios.

Rigging Actions: (Costs 10 NP)

  • Jump In/Out: Switch control between the Engineer and a machine.
  • Command: Issue a basic command (e.g., attack, move, defend). Using your Intelligence + Piloting or Heavy Weapons skill
  • Reconfigure: Change rigged machine’s operational mode (e.g., stealth, aggressive).

Dice pools are based on the Engineer's relevant skill (e.g., Pilot, Heavy Weapons) but using the Engineer’s intelligence as the main attribute.
However, rigging is not without its risks, as it requires an Engineer to divide their attention between their physical body and the controlled machine, making them vulnerable to both physical and cyber threats
Risks/Downsides:

  • Noise Interference: Risk of losing control or reduced effectiveness in areas with high electronic noise. On a Glitch, your sensors get overwhelmed by interference for a round.
  • System Overload: Continuously operating or switching from machine to machine rapidly can lead to system overload. After three consecutive actions without rest, roll 1d6; a roll of 1 or 2 results in a temporary system shutdown.
  • Vulnerability: While 'jumped in', the Engineer's physical body is more vulnerable to attacks.
